questions.question: Which of the following best describes nuclear fission?
options: The combining of two light nuclei to form a heavier one.
The splitting of a heavy, unstable nucleus into two smaller, more stable nuclei.
The emission of an alpha particle from a nucleus.
The conversion of a proton into a neutron.
questions.explanation: Fission: heavy nucleus (e.g., U-235, Pu-239) splits into medium-mass fragments + neutrons + energy. Example: $^{235}\text{U} + n \rightarrow ^{141}\text{Ba} + ^{92}\text{Kr} + 3n + \text{energy}$. Typically triggered by neutron absorption.

questions.question: In a nuclear reactor, 'Chain Reactions' are sustained by the continuous release and absorption of:
questions.explanation: Fission releases 2-3 neutrons per event. For sustained chain reaction: exactly 1 neutron from each fission causes another fission. Controlled in reactors; uncontrolled in bombs. Moderators slow neutrons, control rods absorb excess.

questions.question: Nuclear Fusion is the process that powers:
options: Commercial nuclear power plants on Earth.
Geothermal energy in the Earth's core.
questions.explanation: Sun's core: ~15 million K, proton-proton chain: $4^1\text{H} \rightarrow ^4\text{He} + 2e^+ + 2\nu_e + \gamma$ + 26.7 MeV. Also CNO cycle in heavier stars. Terrestrial fusion not yet commercially viable (research: ITER, JET).

questions.question: Why does nuclear fusion require extremely high temperatures (millions of degrees)?
options: To melt the nuclei into a liquid.
To give the nuclei enough kinetic energy to overcome the strong electrostatic repulsion between positive protons.
To create enough gravity to pull the atoms together.
To prevent the electrons from interfering with the reaction.
questions.explanation: Coulomb barrier: proton repulsion at ~$10^{-14}$ m requires ~0.1 MeV kinetic energy → temperature ~$10^9$ K. Quantum tunneling reduces required temp to ~$10^7$ K. Tokamaks use magnetic confinement, inertial confinement uses lasers.

questions.question: Which process produces more energy per kilogram of fuel?
questions.explanation: Energy per kg: Fusion (~$3.4\times 10^{14}$ J/kg, D-T), Fission (~$8.2\times 10^{13}$ J/kg, U-235), Chemical (~$5\times 10^7$ J/kg, gasoline). Fusion ~4× fission, ~10⁷× chemical. Sun: 600 million tons H → 596 million tons He/sec.

questions.question: In a fission reactor, 'Control Rods' are used to:
options: Absorb excess neutrons to regulate or stop the chain reaction.
Heat the water to produce steam.
Act as the primary fuel source.
questions.explanation: Control rods: Boron, Cadmium, Hafnium (strong neutron absorbers). Insert/withdraw to maintain criticality ($k=1$). Safety: scram = rapid insertion to stop reaction. Moderator (water, graphite) slows neutrons to thermal energies.

questions.question: Which of the following is a major disadvantage of current nuclear fission power?
options: It requires temperatures of millions of degrees.
The fuel (Uranium) is as common as sand.
questions.explanation: Fission products: Sr-90 ($T_{1/2}=29$ y), Cs-137 ($T_{1/2}=30$ y), transuranics like Pu-239 (24,000 y). Storage: geological repositories, vitrification. Fusion: minimal radioactive waste (activated structure materials).

questions.question: According to the Binding Energy Curve, fission occurs in ________ nuclei, while fusion occurs in ________ nuclei.
questions.explanation: Binding energy per nucleon peaks at Fe-56 (~8.8 MeV/n). Fission: heavy nuclei (U-235: ~7.6 MeV/n) → medium (Ba, Kr: ~8.5 MeV/n) releases ~0.9 MeV/n. Fusion: light (H: 0, D: 1.1 MeV/n) → He-4 (7.1 MeV/n) releases ~6 MeV/n.

questions.question: A 'Critical Mass' is defined as:
options: The weight of a single atom.
The minimum amount of fissile material needed to sustain a self-supporting chain reaction.
The total mass of the Sun.
The mass of the waste produced by a reactor.
questions.explanation: Critical mass depends on: enrichment, density, geometry, neutron reflectors. U-235: ~52 kg (sphere, no reflector), ~15 kg (with reflector). Plutonium-239: ~10 kg. Subcritical: $k<1$, critical: $k=1$, supercritical: $k>1$ (explosive).

questions.question: What is the primary 'fuel' for fusion researchers trying to create 'clean' energy on Earth?
questions.explanation: D-T fusion: $^2\text{H} + ^3\text{H} \rightarrow ^4\text{He} + n + 17.6\text{MeV}$. Deuterium: from seawater (1 in 6700 H atoms). Tritium: bred from lithium ($n + ^6\text{Li} \rightarrow ^4\text{He} + ^3\text{H}$). D-D fusion harder but no tritium.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! Mastery of nuclear fission and fusion including mechanisms, energy comparisons, reactor components, binding energy implications, and practical challenges of terrestrial fusion energy.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Strong understanding of fission/fusion principles. Review: 1) Fission vs. fusion definitions and examples, 2) Chain reaction control, 3) Temperature requirements for fusion, 4) Binding energy curve applications, 5) Advantages/disadvantages of each.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Basic fission (splitting heavy) vs. fusion (combining light), 2) Role of neutrons in chain reactions, 3) Why fusion needs high temperatures, 4) Relative energy outputs, 5) Practical applications and challenges.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: Review how fission splits heavy nuclei releasing energy, how fusion combines light nuclei (powering stars), and how both processes move elements toward iron on the binding energy curve.
